title.value: Adjusting Machine Learning Decisions for Equal Opportunity and Counterfactual Fairness
title.justification: It directly matches the title in the provided research paper details.
title.quote: Adjusting Machine Learning Decisions for Equal Opportunity and Counterfactual Fairness

extractions.description: In this paper, two algorithms are proposed to adjust fitted ML predictors to produce decisions that are fair. The paper implements machine learning methodologies considering causal models of ML decisions to define counterfactual fairness and equal opportunity. These algorithms focus on post-hoc adjustments to existing predictors without the need for retraining. The efficacy of these algorithms is demonstrated on datasets involving admissions, income, credit, and recidivism.

type.justification: The paper involves practical implementation and assessment of algorithms on several datasets to adjust ML predictors for fairness.
type.quote: We evaluate the algorithms, and the trade-off between accuracy and fairness, on datasets about admissions, income, credit, and recidivism.

name.justification: The focus of the research is on developing methodologies to adjust machine learning predictors to ensure fairness in high-stakes decisions.
name.quote: In this paper, we propose two algorithms that adjust fitted ML predictors to produce decisions that are fair.

name.justification: The research proposes and evaluates algorithms that ensure fairness criteria in machine learning decisions.
name.quote: In this paper, we propose two algorithms that adjust fitted ML predictors to produce decisions that are fair.

name.justification: The methodology used involves causal inference to define fairness through counterfactual decisions.
name.quote: Our methods provide post-hoc adjustments to the predictors, without requiring that they be retrained. We consider a causal model of the ML decisions, define fairness through counterfactual decisions within the model, and then form algorithmic decisions that capture the historical data as well as possible, but are provably fair.

name.justification: The paper uses logistic regression as a baseline ML decision-maker for binary decision making.
name.quote: First we require that the historical decision-making process is captured by a causal model... then use the historical data to fit an ml method to predict the decision, such as with a simple logistic regression or a neural network.
